data.title: Big day for donors at Hussain Blood Drive
data.meta_description: DRIVEN TO HELP—Above, high school volunteers Insiya Naqvi and Alishey Naqvi check donors in at the Imam Hussain Blood Drive on Sept. 22 at Masjid Al-Rasool mosque in Simi Valley. Top right, Imam Aga Modarres, left, president of Masjid Al-Rasool, shakes hands with Mike McAdams of the Ventura County Red Cross. The Arabic writing behind
data.text:
The Shia Muslim community of Simi Valley held its third annual Imam Hussain Blood Drive on Sept. 22 at the Masjid Al-Rasool mosque in Simi Valley.

The drive was in coordination with the American Red Cross and the Imamia Medics International Organization.

The event was held in the name of Imam Hussain during the Islamic month of Muharram.

The drive has grown from 37 donors the first year to 110 registered donors this year, which required three bloodmobiles, organizers said.

Enough blood was collected from members of Masjid Al-Rasool and the Fatima Islamic Society to save 240 lives.

Hussain was one of Prophet Muhammad’s grandsons from the 7th century. His martyrdom during the Battle of Karbala made him a highly revered figure in the Middle East. His heroic fight against tyranny, injustice and oppression has inspired millions.

Hussain gave his life and sacrificed 72 of his family members to counter the evils in society and to stand up for the principles of peace and reformation.

His battle was against the tyrannical caliph of the time, Yazid, in the land of Karbala, Iraq.

The imam at Masjid Al- Rasool, Aga Modarres, and Mike McAdams, accounts manager of the Ventura County Red Cross, have worked in collaboration for three years and will continue to work together on the blood drive.
